item.title: Contact sports can cause brain injuries. Should kids still play?
item.content:encoded: Modifying rules and grouping players by size rather than age can limit the risks

item.title: For the first time, a CRISPR drug treats a child’s unique mutation
item.content:encoded: Scientists hope more children will benefit

item.title: The race to build the fighter planes of the future
item.content:encoded: They can hold more fuel, carry more weaponry and boast more computing power

item.title: Britain is now the biggest funder of solar-geoengineering research
item.content:encoded: It is supporting experiments to thicken sea ice and make clouds more reflective

item.title: Are juice shots worth the price?
item.content:encoded: Fresh fruit is probably a cheaper alternative

item.title: Companies have plans to build robotic horses
item.content:encoded: One diminutive design is aimed at children

item.title: Compressed music might be harmful to the ears
item.content:encoded: In guinea pigs it can weaken muscles important for hearing

item.title: How to build strong magnets without rare-earth metals
item.content:encoded: China’s export restrictions may boost scientific innovation

item.title: Dogs really do look and act just like their owners
item.content:encoded: The resemblance increases over time

item.title: Is your hay fever getting worse?
item.content:encoded: Climate change could be to blame

item.title: A landmark study of gender medicine is caught in an ethics row
item.content:encoded: Some say the trial is unethical. Others, that not doing it would be immoral

item.title: Rates of bowel cancer are rising among young people
item.content:encoded: Childhood exposure to a common gut bacterium could be responsible

item.title: The great Iberian power cut need not spell disaster for renewables
item.content:encoded: But there are lessons to be learned

item.title: Can at-home brain stimulators make you feel better?
item.content:encoded: For now, the evidence for neuromodulation products is slim

item.title: Australia’s dingoes are becoming a distinct species
item.content:encoded: Many will still be culled under false pretences

item.title: Lethal fungi are becoming drug-resistant—and spreading
item.content:encoded: New antifungals offer a glimmer of hope

item.title: AI models can learn to conceal information from their users
item.content:encoded: This makes it harder to ensure that they remain transparent

item.title: The Carthaginians weren’t who you think they were
item.content:encoded: New research shows just how diverse the ancient city of Dido was

item.title: We’re hiring a Technical Lead for our AI Lab
item.content:encoded: Join The Economist’s new AI initiative

item.title: How to form good habits, and break bad ones: trick your brain
item.content:encoded: Small rewards and a change of scenery can help

item.title: AI models could help negotiators secure peace deals
item.content:encoded: Some are being developed to help end the war in Ukraine

item.title: Scientists are getting to grips with ice
item.content:encoded: Climate change is making water freeze in unexpected ways

item.title: Microplastics have not yet earned their bad reputation
item.content:encoded: There are worrying signs. But more thorough studies of their health effects are coming

item.title: Electric vehicles also cause air pollution
item.content:encoded: Though fume-free, their brake pads and tyres disintegrate over time

item.title: AI models are helping dirty industries go green
item.content:encoded: Mining companies and steelmakers are feeling the benefits

item.title: Could data centres ever be built in orbit?
item.content:encoded: A startup called Starcloud has plans to do just that

item.title: The tricky task of calculating AI’s energy use
item.content:encoded: Making models less thirsty may not lessen their environmental impact

item.title: AI models can help generate cleaner power
item.content:encoded: Energy companies are using them to increase efficiency and spot problems

item.title: Researchers lift the lid on how reasoning models actually “think”
item.content:encoded: They plan sentences far in advance. They also bullshit themselves when reasoning out loud

item.title: How Daylight Saving Time affects your sleep and diet
item.content:encoded: This annual time shift has long-lasting effects on health

item.title: Motors in the wheels take EVs further
item.content:encoded: Simpler to build, lighter and extra range

item.title: What does space miso taste like?
item.content:encoded: It should make the diets of astronauts more interesting

item.title: Mitochondria transplants could cure diseases and lengthen lives
item.content:encoded: A technique that may create a new field of medicine

item.title: Is red meat unhealthy?
item.content:encoded: Overdoing it could give you heart disease or cancer

item.title: Can Musk put people on Mars?
item.content:encoded: Whether successful or not, his attempt to do so will reshape America’s space programme

item.title: Climate change may make it harder to spot submarines
item.content:encoded: The sound of their engines will not travel as far

item.title: How harmful are electronic cigarettes?
item.content:encoded: The risks of vaping may be worth the benefits

item.title: Why don’t seals drown?
item.content:encoded: They can time their dives to match their blood oxygen

item.title: Rumours on social media could cause sick people to feel worse
item.content:encoded: They are powerful triggers of an inverse placebo effect

item.title: Can people be persuaded not to believe disinformation?
item.content:encoded: AI chatbots and critical thinking courses might help

item.title: Do viruses trigger Alzheimer’s?
item.content:encoded: A growing group of scientists think so, and are asking whether antivirals could treat the disease

item.title: What is the best way to keep your teeth healthy?
item.content:encoded: Tooth-brushing reigns supreme. But fluoride in tap water is a good safety net

item.title: Ukraine’s embrace of drone warfare has paid off
item.content:encoded: Two new reports highlight strengths as well as weaknesses

item.title: The race is on to build the world’s most complex machine
item.content:encoded: But toppling ASML will not be easy

item.title: Want even tinier chips? Use a particle accelerator
item.content:encoded: High-speed electrons can etch nano-scale designs

item.title: Is butter bad for you?
item.content:encoded: A new study suggests olive oil may be a healthier alternative

item.title: Two private companies reach the Moon within four days
item.content:encoded: Though Firefly Aerospace has had better luck than Intuitive Machines

item.title: Satellites are polluting the stratosphere
item.content:encoded: And forthcoming mega-constellations will exacerbate the problem

item.title: AI models are dreaming up the materials of the future
item.content:encoded: Better batteries, cleaner bioplastics and more powerful semiconductors await

item.title: Mice have been genetically engineered to look like mammoths
item.content:encoded: They are small and tuskless, but extremely fluffy

item.title: Is posh moisturiser worth the money?
item.content:encoded: Don’t break the bank

item.title: How artificial intelligence can make board games better
item.content:encoded: It can iron out glitches in the rules before they go on the market

item.title: The skyrocketing demand for minerals will require new technologies
item.content:encoded: Flexible drills, distributed power systems and, of course, artificial intelligence

item.content:encoded: The key is to fly very low indeed

item.title: Do better shoes help you run faster?
item.content:encoded: Yes, but the benefits won’t last

item.content:encoded: The consequences will be felt around the world

item.content:encoded: DNA analysis reveals shifting family patterns

item.content:encoded: What could have generated the most energetic neutrino ever detected?

item.content:encoded: Moneyball enters its AI era

item.title: Forget DeepSeek. Large language models are getting cheaper still

item.title: Does intermittent fasting work?
item.content:encoded: It does for weight loss. Its other supposed benefits are debatable

item.title: Cryptocurrencies are spawning a new generation of private eyes
item.content:encoded: Their tools are software, and a nose for trouble

item.title: Fine-tuned acoustic waves can knock drones out of the sky
item.content:encoded: The right sounds can also disable their cameras

item.content:encoded: Drone operators and jammers are in a high-tech arms race

item.title: Are ice baths good for you?
item.content:encoded: They won’t hurt. Actually they might, a bit

item.title: Why carbon monoxide could appeal to the discerning doper
item.content:encoded: Professional cycling is debating whether to ban the poisonous gas

item.title: A sophisticated civilisation once flourished in the Amazon basin
item.content:encoded: How the Casarabe died out remains a mystery

item.title: Heritable Agriculture, a Google spinout, is bringing AI to crop breeding
item.content:encoded: By reducing the cost of breeding, the firm hopes to improve yields and other properties for an array of important crops

item.title: Could supersonic air travel make a comeback?
item.content:encoded: Boom Supersonic’s demonstrator jet exceeds Mach 1

item.title: Should you worry about microplastics?
item.content:encoded: Little is known about the effects on humans—but limiting exposure to them seems prudent

item.title: Wasps stole genes from viruses
item.content:encoded: That probably assisted their evolutionary diversification

item.title: America’s departure from the WHO would harm everyone
item.content:encoded: Whether it is a negotiating ploy remains to be seen

item.title: Genetic engineering could help rid Australia of toxic cane toads
item.content:encoded: It is better than freezing them to death

item.title: High-tech antidotes for snake bites
item.content:encoded: Genetic engineering and AI are powering the search for antivenins

item.title: Can you breathe stress away?
item.content:encoded: It won’t hurt to try. But scientists are only beginning to understand the links between the breath and the mind

item.title: The Economist’s science and technology internship
item.content:encoded: We invite applications for the 2025 Richard Casement internship

item.title: A better understanding of Huntington’s disease brings hope
item.content:encoded: Previous research seems to have misinterpreted what is going on

item.title: Is obesity a disease?
item.content:encoded: It wasn’t. But it is now

item.title: Volunteers with Down’s syndrome could help find Alzheimer’s drugs
item.content:encoded: Those with the syndrome have more of a protein implicated in dementia

item.title: Should you start lifting weights?
item.content:encoded: You’ll stay healthier for longer if you’re strong

item.title: Does melatonin work for jet lag?
item.content:encoded: It can help. But it depends where you’re going

item.title: Training AI models might not need enormous data centres
item.content:encoded: Eventually, models could be trained without any dedicated hardware at all

item.title: How the Gulf’s rulers want to harness the power of science
item.content:encoded: A stronger R&D base, they hope, will transform their countries’ economies. Will their plan work?

item.title: Cancer vaccines are showing promise at last
item.content:encoded: Trials are under way against skin, brain and lung tumours

item.title: New firefighting tech is being trialled in Sardinia’s ancient forests
item.content:encoded: It could sniff out blazes long before they spread out of control

item.title: Can Jeff Bezos match Elon Musk in space?
item.content:encoded: After 25 years, Blue Origin finally heads to orbit, and hopes to become a contender in the private space race

item.title: Why some doctors are reassessing hypnosis
item.content:encoded: There is growing evidence that it can help with pain, depression and more

item.title: Academic writing is getting harder to read—the humanities most of all
item.content:encoded: We analyse two centuries of scholarly work

item.title: Giving children the wrong (or not enough) toys may doom a society
item.content:encoded: Survival is a case of child’s play

item.title: Earth is warming faster. Scientists are closing in on why
item.content:encoded: Paradoxically, cleaner emissions from ships and power plants are playing a role

item.title: Humans and Neanderthals met often, but only one event matters
item.content:encoded: The mystery of exactly how people left Africa deepens

item.content:encoded: But interpreting meanings, rather than just words and sentences, will be a daunting task

item.title: AI can bring back a person’s own voice
item.content:encoded: And it can generate sentences trained on their own writing

item.title: Carbon emissions from tourism are rising disproportionately fast
item.content:encoded: The industry is failing to make itself greener

item.title: Why China is building a Starlink system of its own
item.content:encoded: When it is finished, Qianfan could number 14,000 satellites, rivalling Elon Musk’s system

item.content:encoded: What they ate is given away by the isotopes in their bodies

item.title: Stimulating parts of the brain can help the paralysed to walk again
item.content:encoded: Implanted electrodes allowed one man to climb stairs unaided

item.content:encoded: And if its boss now tries to kill NASA’s own heavy lifter, will that matter?

item.title: Dreams of asteroid mining, orbital manufacturing and much more
item.content:encoded: Ideas for making money in orbit that seemed mad in the 1960s now look sane

item.title: Elon Musk is causing problems for the Royal Society
item.content:encoded: His continued membership has led to a high-profile resignation

item.title: Deforestation is costing Brazilian farmers millions
item.content:encoded: Without trees to circulate moisture, the land is getting hotter and drier

item.title: Robots can learn new actions faster thanks to AI techniques
item.content:encoded: They could soon show their moves in settings from car factories to care homes

item.title: Scientists are learning why ultra-processed foods are bad for you
item.content:encoded: A mystery is finally being solved

item.title: Scientific publishers are producing more papers than ever
item.content:encoded: Concerns about some of their business models are building

item.title: The two types of human laugh
item.content:encoded: One is caused by tickling; the other by everything else

item.title: Scientists are building a catalogue of every type of cell in our bodies
item.content:encoded: It has thus far shed light on everything from organ formation to the causes of inflammation

item.content:encoded: Cephalopod ink propulsion is inspiring an alternative to syringes

item.content:encoded: More accurate predictions will lead to better policy-making

item.title: Physics reveals the best design for a badminton arena
item.content:encoded: The key is minimising the disruptive effects of ventilation

item.title: There’s lots of gold in urban waste dumps
item.content:encoded: The pay dirt could be 15 times richer than natural deposits

item.title: A battle is raging over the definition of open-source AI
item.content:encoded: Companies that bet on the right one could win big

item.title: As wellness trends take off, iodine deficiency makes a quiet comeback
item.content:encoded: Levels of the vital nutrient are falling rapidly in America

item.title: How blood-sucking vampire bats get their energy
item.content:encoded: They pull off a trick previously thought unique to a few insects

item.title: China plans to crash a spacecraft into a distant asteroid
item.content:encoded: It will be only the second country to conduct such a planetary defence experiment

item.title: Researchers are questioning if ADHD should be seen as a disorder
item.content:encoded: It should, instead, be seen as a different way of being normal

item.content:encoded: The problem of variable buoyancy is being overcome

item.title: Space may be worse for humans than thought
item.content:encoded: Why going into orbit sends cells haywire

item.title: Heart-cockle shells may work like fibre-optic cables
item.content:encoded: Inbuilt lenses transmit sunlight to symbiotic algae

item.title: Winemakers are building grape-picking robots
item.content:encoded: Automating this delicate task is harder than it seems

item.title: Why Oriental hornets can’t get drunk
item.content:encoded: They can guzzle extreme amounts for their size, without suffering ill effects

item.title: The study of ancient DNA is helping to solve modern crimes
item.content:encoded: Such techniques have helped secure two convictions this year

item.title: Perovskite crystals may represent the future of solar power
item.content:encoded: Their efficiency rates far exceed those of conventional silicon panels

item.title: SpaceX is NASA’s biggest lunar rival
item.content:encoded: The company’s successes are also showing up the agency’s failings

item.title: Tubeworms live beneath the planetary crust around deep-sea vents
item.content:encoded: The conditions are hot, sulphurous and low in oxygen

item.title: Elon Musk’s SpaceX has achieved something extraordinary

item.content:encoded: The award honours protein design and the use of AI for protein-structure prediction

item.content:encoded: These tiny molecules regulate genes and control how cells develop and behave

item.title: An adult fruit fly brain has been mapped—human brains could follow

item.content:encoded: Across Europe, nearly a quarter of water goes to waste

item.title: NASA is selling a brand-new Moon rover

item.content:encoded: Mining for raw materials may peak by the mid-2030s

item.title: Earth may once have had a planetary ring
item.content:encoded: It would have collapsed 450m years ago

item.content:encoded: Non-native species are not always harmful

item.content:encoded: Tricks from the oil industry have produced a hot-rocks breakthrough

item.content:encoded: It would be 1,000 times more accurate than today’s atomic timekeepers

item.content:encoded: Some of its myriad components are being tested as treatments for cancer and other diseases

item.content:encoded: All it takes is very long radio waves

item.content:encoded: The effect is small but consistent

item.title: Digital twins are making companies more efficient

item.content:encoded: Flying on Elon Musk’s spaceship; sponsored by Doritos

item.content:encoded: A successful jab would be a boon to fish farmers
